data.meta_description: From the most-played dance hits to popular karaoke ballads, get ready to party with these â€™80s hits, including Prince, Madonna and U2.
data.text:
Where do we even begin with defining the â€˜80s? Though itâ€™s remembered by those who were there as an era of colourful, garish fashion, perms and shoulder pads, the decade was also one of remarkably varied and innovative music, and â€˜80s influences have seeped into songs produced ever since.

Some of our biggest stars had their golden era in the 80s, from Madonna to Kate Bush, Marvin Gaye to Paul Simon. But it wasnâ€™t just a time of explosion for their success â€“ there are plenty of New Wave artists on our list, too. Keep an eye out for the likes of the Talking Heads, NWA and Biz Markie when youâ€™re having a scroll. Here are our picks for the best â€˜80s songs ever made.

1. â€˜I Wanna Dance with Somebodyâ€™ by Whitney Houston

In 1987, Houston was still very much a fresh-faced siren with the crystal-clear voice and a world of possibilities at her feet. Her approach to this song â€“ which, when you break it down, is more about loneliness than love â€“ says a lot about her ability to radiate warmth and positivity through her singular sound. It's miles away from the struggles the singer would face later in her career. Always a party starter and roof-igniting karaoke jam, the song become a bittersweet rallying cry in the years since her death, still urging every last wallflower on to the dance floor.

2. â€˜The Perfect Kissâ€™ by New Order

Sure, the album version of â€˜The Perfect Kissâ€™ (on 1985â€™s â€˜Low Lifeâ€™) is also an excellent song; a glitzy, funky display from a â€™80s seminal pop bands at the height of their powers. But this version is the one thatâ€™s most glorious. Released as a single and included on the 1987 â€˜Substanceâ€™ compilation, you get all of the OG tune plus an extra couple of minutes of outro that only adds further impact to Peter Hookâ€™s low-slung, thumping bass, the ribbiting frog textures and head-spinning synth hits.

Ed Cunningham

News Editor, Time Out UK and Time Out London

Advertising

3. â€˜Everywhereâ€™ by Fleetwood Mac

Despite being one of the later singles from Fleetwoodâ€™s era-defining album and only achieving moderate chart success upon release, youâ€™d be hard-pressed to come by someone who doesnâ€™t have to fight the urge to tap, hum and sway in time to this luxurious, sensory track. Is it the angelic backing choir, the tingly opening bells, or the impossibly smooth layers, that make it so addictive? Who knows. What we do know is this has to be one of the most pleasing songs of the decade.

4. â€˜Modern Loveâ€™ by David Bowie

Bowie was all over the place during the â€™80s: duetting with Jagger, clambering into spandex for Labyrinth, getting buried alive for Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence and ultimately embarking on a midlife crisis that resulted in a worrying beard and Tin Machine. But before all that, he managed to lay down some of the decadeâ€™s best tracks, including this nihilistic, Nile Rodgersâ€“assisted soul boogie from 1983. We defy your feet to stay on the floor as that cyclical, cynical, irresistible chorus hurtles on.

James Manning

Content Director, EMEA

Advertising

5. â€˜Once in a Lifetimeâ€™ by Talking Heads

You really have Brian Eno to thank for â€˜Once In A Lifetimeâ€™. Under his guidance, Talking Heads pieced together snippets of jam sessions and the beginning of a song titled â€˜Right Startâ€™ to (unbeknown to them) create a moment in music history. Tina Weymouthâ€™s distinctive bassline, Jerry Harrisonâ€™s bubbling synthesiser and Byrneâ€™s sermon-inspired half-singing half-talking all collide to create something incredible. Itâ€™s an art pop anthem unlike anything else of its time.

Georgia Evans

Commercial Editor, Time Out

6. â€˜Express Yourselfâ€™ by Madonna

Madge spend the entirety of the â€˜80s practicing what she preached on this career-defining smash, among the last of her â€˜80s mega-hits and the crowning achievement of the Like a Prayer album. Itâ€™s a glorious encapsulation of a first act that included â€˜Lucky Star,â€™ â€˜Like a Virgin,â€™ â€˜Material Girl,â€™ Borderline,â€™Papa Donâ€™t Preachâ€™ and â€˜True Blueâ€™ â€“ any of which could easily hold their own on this list. But â€˜Express Yourselfâ€™ wasnâ€™t just a stadium-ready anthem for the queen of pop: Itâ€™s an eternal anthem for anyone looking for a song about their own embrace of individuality.

Advertising

7. â€˜Purple Rainâ€™ by Prince

Prince was so prolific in the '80s that 90% of this list could be his and it would still be correct. But forced to pick one Prince song, â€˜Purple Rainâ€™ is the obvious choice. Itâ€™s a swelling, perfectly crafted masterpiece that spotlights everything that made Prince Rogers Nelson an absolute legend: his gift for unique melodies; his multinstrumentalism; his uncanny vocal ability to shift from guttural to falsetto, from aggrieved to ethereal; and his unmatched ability to absolutely slay a guitar solo. It's Prince at his best, a song that remains as impactful today as it was nearly 40 years ago.

8. â€˜Fight the Powerâ€™ by Public Enemy

â€˜Nineteen eighty-nineâ€¦â€™ The first five syllables of Public Enemyâ€™s most zeitgeisty hit, made at the request of Spike Lee for his groundbreaking film Do the Right Thing, pack a ton of punch. And it only gets more intense from there, building a manifesto of what to take swigs at, including this gem: â€™Elvis was a hero to most / But he never meant shit to me / You see, straight-up racist that sucker was / Simple and plain / Mother-fuck him and John Wayne / Cuz I'm black and I'm prou.â€™ And thatâ€™s the truth, Ruth.

Advertising

9. â€˜The Messageâ€™ by Grandmaster Flash and The Furious Five

With its synthed-out beat and terse â€˜don't push me â€˜cuz I'm close to the edge,â€™ Flashâ€™s legendary contribution to the hip-hop era wasn't just a banger: It announced to the world that hip-hop wasn't an idle pastime. Here was a movement that had just as much to say as the protest-obsessed hippies of the â€™60sâ€¦ the very same music fans who inexplicably pushed back against the music of young, assertive and frustrated Black men looking to raise awareness and change the world through music.

10. â€˜Straight Outta Comptonâ€™ by NWA

The title of the track of NWA's debut doesn't just announce the arrival of Dr. Dre, Ice Cube, Eazy-E and MC Ren. It announced the arrival of west-coast rap in the most aggressive, game-changing way imaginable, leaving the dominant hair rockers of the time little choice but to get out of the way. There are only a few moments in musical history where you can feel a tectonic synced perfectly to the beat. This is one of them.

Advertising

11. â€˜Close to Meâ€™ by the Cure

Robert Smithâ€™s un-merry men spent roughly half of the â€™80s making desperately sad goth rock, and the other half writing some of the best pop songs of all time. Naturally, there was a certain amount of leakage between the two â€“ which is why 1985â€™s â€˜Close to Meâ€™ is a strong contender for the bandâ€™s best song, with its yearning lyrics matched by ultra perky brass riffs (inspired by a New Orleans funeral march, obvs). Thereâ€™s also an album version of this without the trumpets, but why would you even want that? James Manning

12. â€˜Cloudbustingâ€™ by Kate Bush

â€˜Running Up That Hillâ€˜? Not even the best track on â€˜Hounds of Loveâ€™, mate. Kate Bushâ€™s ability to distil esoteric source works into visionary pop songs is, of course, most famously manifested in â€˜Wuthering Heightsâ€™. â€˜Cloudbustingâ€™ is adapted from a much stranger work: Peter Reichâ€™s â€˜A Book of Dreamsâ€™, his memoir of growing up as the child of psychiatrist and philosopher Wilhelm Reich. Itâ€™s very weird, basically, but what Bush did with it is remarkable, a five-minute fable of childish love and terror set to quite extraordinary music, rhythmic strings that are gradually overtaken by crashing waves of military drums. Itâ€™s overwhelmingly emotional and quite possibly the best-produced song of the entire decade.

Advertising

13. â€˜Sexual Healingâ€™ by Marvin Gaye

Gaye already gifted the world arguably the greatest song about sex ever, â€˜Letâ€™s Get It On,â€™ in 1973. Nine years later, though, he came awfully close to outdoing himself with â€˜Sexual Healing,â€™ his first non-Motown single (released just two years before he was fatally shot by his father). The steamy track is decidedly more â€™80s, with a drum-machine propulsion, busy guitars and a pleasing base of synths. It also boasts perhaps the most fitting last line in a sex song to date: â€˜Please don't procrastinate / Itâ€™s not good to masturbate.â€™

14. â€˜Dancing in the Darkâ€™ by Bruce Springsteen

The Boss pinched the title of an old croonersâ€™ standard to write his own classic, the finest single from his massive Born in the USA album in 1984. Bursting with ambition, frustration and sex, â€˜Dancing in the Darkâ€™ is also Springsteenâ€™s dance-floor peak, with a typically stunning sax solo by the late Clarence Clemons to top it all off. And there arenâ€™t many songs from the era that come with an important warning about fire safety in the chorus.

Advertising

15. â€˜Whatâ€™s Love Got to Do With Itâ€™ by Tina Turner

In 1984, Tina Turner was 44 and on the comeback trail. Having finally split from her abusive husband and artistic Svengali, Ike, sheâ€™d spent years in a limbo of cameos, Vegas shows and dud solo albums. But the hit album Private Dancer and its chart-topping single, â€˜Whatâ€™s Love Got to Do with Itâ€™ â€“ her first top-10 song in more than a decade â€“ made the tough soul icon a solo superstar. The video found her strutting around New York City in a jean jacket, leather miniskirt and feather-duster hair â€“ a bruised but defiantly happy paragon of independence.

16. â€˜Beat Itâ€™ by Michael Jackson

We get so used to the sleek, funky side of Michael Jackson on the hit parade that was Thriller that it's easy to forget how hard â€˜Beat Itâ€™ actually legitimately rocks. And it's not just Eddie Van Halen's famous finger-busting solo; itâ€™s that perfectly formed sneer of a guitar riff â€“ conceived by Jackson and played by session ace Steve Lukather â€“ those exaggered downbeats that feel like medicine balls being slammed down on a concrete floor and the raw desperation in MJâ€™s voice as he chronicles the harsh truths of the street-fighting life. As much of a dance-floor killer as it is, â€˜Beat Itâ€™ is a genuinely heavy song, psychologically as much as sonically.

Advertising

17. â€˜Love Will Tear Us Apartâ€™ by Joy Division

Although forever bound up in the tragic legend of Joy Division vocalist Ian Curtis â€“ who died by suicide shortly before its release â€“ â€˜Love Will Tear Us Apartâ€™ doesnâ€˜t need any myth-making to stand as a work of genius. Itâ€™s an overwhelming roar of melancholy melody, almost Phil Spector-ish in its breadth of sound, exquisitely offsetting Curtisâ€˜s mournful, mannered lyric about the collapse of his marriage. That the surviving members of the band almost immediately formed the pioneering New Order is nothing short of remarkable.

18. â€˜Come on Eileenâ€™ by Dexys Midnight Runners

Maybe not surprising, coming from a band named after an amphetamine, but the UK group propels the juddering rhythms of its classic 1982 single like a dynamo, chugging through tempo changes while picking up steam for the big finish. The lyrics, about songwriter Kevin Rowland's youth as a sexually repressed Catholic kid, verge on dirty while remaining innocuous enough for your work-party karaoke sing-along.

Advertising

19. â€˜You Make My Dreamsâ€™ by Hall & Oates

Is this the happiest song ever written? Quite possibly. Thereâ€™s a bounce to â€˜You Make My Dreamsâ€™ that is ridiculously infectious â€“ you canâ€™t hear the â€˜Ooh-ooh, ooh-ooh-oohâ€™ without smiling or wanting to get up and dance with a loved one. Its catchy chorus is the perfect embodiment of those early moments of love and your excitement for whatever the future may hold. Hall & Oates may have made a name for themselves via soft rock and smooth-jazz-inspired diddies about stained and complicated romance, but â€˜You Make My Dreamsâ€™ is an unashamedly optimistic banger. Georgia Evans

20. â€˜How Soon Is Now?â€™ by The Smiths

Yes, singer Morrissey has not gone on to cover himself in glory. But the fact that anyone even knows who he is nowadays now is entirely a testament to how extraordinary The Smiths were. Any number of their songs could slot in here, but itâ€™s understandable why â€˜How Soon Is Now?â€™ is generally held to be The One, Morrisseyâ€™s simple but perfectly formed lyric about â€˜a shyness that is criminally vulgarâ€™ meeting Johnny Marrâ€™s remarkable music, a strange and entirely intoxicating mix of clubby bottom end and swampily reverberating slide guitar that sounds like nothing else made before or since.

Advertising

21. â€˜Everybody Wants to Rule the Worldâ€™ by Tears for Fears

We may dismiss the â€™80s as an era of musical cheese, light on substance and heavy on excess. But the decade delivered some of musicâ€™s most emotional, teary moments, the more affecting for the fact that the vehicle is pop. This 1985 hit by Tears for Fears is one such song, an existential meditation of sorts, opening with the line, â€˜Welcome to your life â€” thereâ€™s no turning back.â€™ Itâ€™s a serious pop song, as bassist-singer Curt Smith remarked: â€˜Itâ€˜s about everybody wanting power, about warfare and the misery it causes.â€™

22. â€˜Every Breath You Takeâ€™ by the Police

Too many people mock the '80s as an age of excess, yet loads of classic singles from the era are studies in cool restraint (see: Phil Collins â€“ no, honestly). Itâ€™s just that they spent a butt-ton of money on everything. So though Stewart Copeland could be a florid, flashy drummer, and though Sting was known to dash a few extra flicks on his grooves, â€˜Every Breathâ€™ measures each note microscopically, as if arranged with OCD, which makes the stalking vibe that much subtly creepier.

Advertising

23. â€˜Just Like Honeyâ€™ by The Jesus and Mary Chain

The first four iconic seconds of the Ronetteâ€™s â€˜Be My Babyâ€™ have been sampled again and again over the past 50 years: Billy Joel, the Magnetic Fields, the Strokes, Amy Winehouse, Dan Deacon, Gotyeâ€¦ the list goes on. But only one band had transformed that groundbreaking phrase into a musical piece that defined an era (almost) as deeply as the Ronettes. The Jesus and Mary Chain's â€˜Just Like Honeyâ€™ captures a certain proto-shoegazey, bittersweet longing that pristinely characterizes the hazy milieu of the â€˜80s â€“ not to mention gave Sophia Coppolaâ€™s Lost In Translation a killer outro a few seconds before the credits roll.

24. â€˜The Sweetest Tabooâ€™ by Sade

Sade is just so damned smooth. It would be easy to be consumed by envy if we weren't all being lulled into a dopey, two-stepping, love-drunk stupor. The Nigerian-born, U.K.-raised singer-songwriter is in top form on this hit single from her multi-platinum-selling second album, Promise. When it comes on, you've got no choice but to relax and drift off into the quiet storm.

Advertising

25. â€˜Should I Stay or Should I Goâ€™ by the Clash

As the 1970s turned in the 1980s, punks and rockers (and there was a difference then) both became enamored with the sounds coming out of New York City. Even the Stones went disco and dabbled with rap. No guitar act better assimilated hip-hop than the Clash, probably because they had so much practice sponging up dub. This final single â€“ or the last that matters, anyway â€“ was a dry run for Mick Jonesâ€™s sampling-loving crew Big Audio Dynamite, a bit of Isley Brothers meets a Bronx boom box. Jones liked it so much he sampled the track a decade later in â€˜The Globe.â€™

26. â€˜Never Gonna Give You Upâ€™ by Rick Astley

The meme known as Rickrolling â€“ wherein someone baits you with an enticing link, which points instead to the video for this 1987 dance-pop smash â€“ always seemed a little puzzling to us, mainly because, like, who wouldn't want to be surprised with another exposure to this suavely buoyant megajam? Those synthesized strings, that thumping boots-and-pants beat, Astleyâ€™s weirdly robust croon and his romantic-wooing-as-used-car-salesman-pitch come-on (â€˜You wouldn't get this from any other guyâ€™)â€¦ It all adds up to three and a half of the most effervescent minutes in the â€™80s canon.

Advertising

27. â€˜Super Freakâ€™ by Rick James

Catchier than a flytrap, more sordid than your craziest night out, Rick James hit the summit of his career with the wild funk of â€˜Super Freak.â€™ A global hit in 1981, the starâ€™s signature song finds him joined by the mighty Temptations on backing vocals â€“ including Jamesâ€™s uncle, Melvin Franklin. Even that sampling by MC Hammer canâ€™t diminish its greatness.

28. â€˜Take On Meâ€™ by A-ha

The first and biggest hit by the Norwegian electropop trio A-ha, â€˜Take On Meâ€™ rose to international popularity in 1985 on the strength of its groundbreaking video, a mix of live-action and pencil-drawn animation that starred dreamy lead singer Morten Harket as the hero of an escapist romance between a lonely woman and a comic-book adventurer. (It won six MTV Video Awards.) The songâ€™s masterfully infectious synth riff would be enough to secure it a spot on any list of â€™80s classics. But â€˜Take On Meâ€™ is also distinguished by Harketâ€™s improbably octave-spanning vocals, whose seeming effortlessness has inspired countless screeching karaoke wipeouts.

Advertising

29. â€˜Just a Friendâ€™ by Biz Markie

Hip-hop hit its golden era in the â€™80s. Biz Markie was both emblematic of the genreâ€™s giddy charms and the man responsible for its ultimate downfall. As critics continued to peg rap as a passing novelty, this big, lisping teddy bear from Long Island thumbed his nose at such stuck-up stupidity. He overtly recycled refuse from popâ€™s past and amped up the humor, daring haters to resist his charms. His records were as much comedy albums and demonstrations of sampling as pretentious works of art, which made them even greater works of art. Eventually, he had the shit sued out of him, and hip-hop was forever changed. But the greater loss is Bizâ€™s sense of self-deprecation. â€˜Just A Friendâ€™ is the opposite of the braggadocio that would become a hallmark of the art form.

30. â€˜All Night Longâ€™ by Lionel Richie

Itâ€™s impossible to feel bad when this tuneâ€™s Caribbean-inflected rhythms start pumping from a nearby speaker. The perma-coifed Commodores frontmanâ€™s 1983 single smashes any attempts to resist its groove. And that bit that sounds like made-up gibberish? It is. Richie attempted to find some suitable foreign phrases but got impatient and invented his own international party language.

Advertising

31. â€˜Africaâ€™ by Toto

Toto was a collection of studio ringers with credits on Steely Dan and Boz Scaggs records. Wrapped in chest hair, sunglasses and terry cloth, these feathery dudes were too anonymous to be deserving of the term supergroup. â€˜Africaâ€™ was their contribution to the wave of telethon pop that clogged the Reagan era, another patronizing plea for charity like â€˜We Are the Worldâ€™ and Band Aid. A Yamaha GS1 synthesizer is made to sound like a mbira; thereâ€™s a gong in there somewhere, for some reason. Itâ€™s Heart of Darkness as told from the tanning deck of a luxury yacht. Thankfully, the lotion-slick groove reeks more of coconuts than crisp money. Oddly, it's become the unofficial theme of the New England Revolution MLS soccer club, and an unexpected mega-hit for Weezer to boot.

32. â€˜Blue Mondayâ€™ by New Order

Eighties synthpop can seem kitsch today because it was so aggressively determined to sound like the future back then. Why is â€˜Blue Mondayâ€™ different? Why does it still feel like the future? From that utterly distinctive bass drum intro to Bernard Sumnerâ€™s eerie, oblique â€˜how does it feel?â€™ vocal, the icy synths, menacing bass, weird gregorian chant sound and much more, New Orderâ€™s seven-and-half-minute masterpiece is both breathtakingly bold and strangely indifferent to the listener, like some vast incomprehensible alien creature. It is the apex of synthpop, a song so daring that it broke ground that nobody â€“ not even New Order â€“ has even tried to cover since.

Advertising

33. â€˜Karma Chameleonâ€™ by Culture Club

There are few â€™80s icons quite as evocative as Boy George, but the British singer is so much more than an icon of style and gender fluidity. There are plenty of mournful songs in Culture Clubâ€™s discography, but in many ways the band stands out as something of a sunny yin to The Cureâ€™s goth yang, and â€˜Karma Chameleonâ€™ is perhaps the most upbeat of them all. It endures as a pick-me-up all these years later, a celebration of the vibrant colors of humanity and the power of a well-placed harmonica line.

34. â€˜Don't You (Forget About Me)â€™ by Simple Minds

Jim Kerrâ€™s soulful yowl was never better than on this fist-raising banger, an earnestly overwrought piece of melancholic pop bliss. Whether you think of it as â€˜the song from The Breakfast Clubâ€™ or â€˜the song that made The Breakfast Club cool,â€™ it's one of the eraâ€™s definitive anthems.

Advertising

35. â€˜Time After Timeâ€™ by Cyndi Lauper

Those who grew up in the '90s should know this from two awesome movie dance scenes: a sexy one in Baz Luhrmannâ€™s Strictly Ballroom and a silly one in Romy and Micheleâ€™s High School Reunion. But for the â€™80s crowd, itâ€™s a classic slow dance that stands up as one of the strongest songs of the decade. Cyndiâ€™s mad orange hair might be dated like lukewarm milk, but â€™Time After Timeâ€™ still smells fresh to us. James Manning

36. â€˜West End Girlsâ€™ by Pet Shop Boys

No â€™80s list would be complete without British synth-popsters the Pet Shop Boys. While the duo achieved its greatest success on home turf, this 1985 ode to London street life was written and recorded in New York, as the pair recalls in our interview, and bristles with urban seediness (note: Itâ€™s partly inspired by T.S. Eliotâ€™s The Wasteland). Thatâ€™s thanks in no small part to Neil Tennantâ€™s coolly annunciated delivery, a hypnotic take on the hip-hop flows of the era.

Advertising

37. â€˜Itâ€™s the End of the World as We Know Itâ€™ by R.E.M

â€˜Thatâ€™s great, it starts with an earthquake,â€™ begins Michael Stipe â€“ and the rumbling and rambling get crazier from there in R.E.M.â€™s ironic beat poem. The lyrics pour out in a nervy jumble of apocalyptic imagery, military danger and mass-media frenzy, with pointed name-drops of pop-culture figures (Lenny Bruce, Leonid Brezhnev, Leonard Bernstein and Lester Bangs) united only by their initials. Unlike its evil twin in 1980s rock, Billy Joelâ€™s â€˜We Didnâ€™t Start the Fire,â€™ the song was not a huge pop hit; on its 1987 album, Document, R.E.M. was still emerging from the niche of college rock. But its cut-through-the-chaos message still connects with anyone aiming to clear out a polluted stream of consciousness.

38. â€˜Tainted Loveâ€™ by Soft Cell

Turning jaunty Motown influences into icy synth pop may sound like sacrilege, but that's exactly what English duo Soft Cell did when it covered Gloria Jonesâ€™s 1965 funky stomper in 1981. Ditching the originalâ€™s energy for Marc Almond's cut-glass tones and unashamedly machine-driven melodies, Soft Cellâ€™s version soon became huge, paving the way for the â€™80s synth-pop explosion that followed.

Advertising

39. â€˜Under Pressureâ€™ by Queen & David Bowie

Oh, that ill-fated bassline. Before Vanilla Ice famously ripped off â€“ er, was inspired by the work of Queen bassist John Deacon, that subtle, infectious plucking heralded the meeting of two wildly influential rock icons. Considering the titanic forces at work in this tune, it's relatively understated, but it does ultimately climb to the sparkling heights that both Bowie and Freddie Mercury inhabited with such ease.

40. â€˜With or Without Youâ€™ by U2

Oh, itâ€™s so easy to mock U2: the bombast, the shades, the pomp, the uninvited infiltration of your iTunesâ€¦ But the bandâ€™s 1987 opus, The Joshua Tree, contains three of its mightiest songs in a row, of which â€˜With or Without Youâ€™ is its most affecting. The songâ€™s bittersweet sentiment is perfectly matched by the music â€” at turns delicate and yearning, then surging and desperate. Play it somewhere you can howl along, loudly. Preferably in the albumâ€™s namesake desert.

Advertising

41. â€˜Where Is My Mind?â€™ by the Pixies

Has a drum introduction ever sounded this big? Those unforgettable snare snaps comes courtesy of producer Steve Albini, and itâ€™s one of the many touches the bandâ€™s most popular song (one that wasnâ€™t even released as a single in â€™88) has going for it: Among the many others, thereâ€™s Kim Dealâ€™' haunting, reverb drenched backing vocals that so many indie-rock groups would go on to ape, a cracked-voiced Black Francis spitting out cryptic-cool lyrics, and deceptively simple lead guitar and bass combo that still gives us goosebumps.

42. â€˜Sweet Child oâ€™ Mineâ€™ by Guns Nâ€™ Roses

If you're in an â€™80s cover band and you're not playing this song on a nightly basis â€” well, there's just absolutely no way youâ€™re not. Of all of the iconic guitar riffs on this list, the opening line from â€˜Sweet Child o' Mineâ€™ takes the air-splitting cake. The third single from Guns Nâ€™ Rosesâ€™ shining debut, 1987â€™s Appetite for Destruction, it was the bandâ€™s first and only number one single. More than three decades on, it never fails to make us sing our fool hearts out on the dance floor.

Advertising

43. â€˜You Can Call Me Alâ€™ by Paul Simon

Paul Simonâ€™s Graceland, in hindsight, seems like an ultra-square reaction to everything the â€™80s stood for: Here was a â€™60s folk rocker teaming up with a cadre of South African musicians for a folksy world-music pop album. But Graceland slaps. Specifically, the lead single slaps, especially on the iconic slap-bass solo fired off nonchalantly by Bakithi Kumalo. What could have been a midlife-crisis misfire instead became a phenomenon.

44. â€˜We Got the Beatâ€™ by the Go-Goâ€™s

Looking back, it's hard to really realize the impact of The Go-Goâ€™s, the first studio-backed all-woman rock band that wrote its own songs. Thatâ€™s because the Go-Go's arrived fully formed, ready to shake the industry with songs like this pop-fueled post-punk anthem that changed rock history the minute the first DJ hit play.

Advertising

45. â€˜Call Meâ€™ by Blondie

Debbie Harry roared into the â€™80s with expected style, her punk/glam credentials firmly in-tact, with this shredder announcing that the New Wave icons of the â€™70s were more than capable of holding their own in a new decade. The song served as the official theme for the Richard Gere film American Gigolo, outliving the movie in sheer relevance by a solid 40 years and counting.

46. â€˜Push Itâ€™ by Salt-N-Pepa

Complexity, be damned! Sometimes all you really need for a truly memorable hit is economy, as proved by this stone-cold classic from 1988. On â€˜Push It,â€™ all-gal Queens hip-hop trio Salt-N-Pepa made pop magic via a seemingly simple combination of Casio beats; a few big, dumb keyboard stabs; and a lot of impassioned, steamy cries of â€˜Ooh, baby baby.â€™

Advertising

47. â€˜Whip Itâ€™ by Devo

Few bands rode the new wave-wave out of the â€™70s punk/CBGB scene with the zany aplomb of Mark Mothersbaugh gang of weirdos, transitioning from the rollicking â€˜Uncontrollable Urgeâ€™ era to the earworm that is â€˜Whip It.â€™ Released in 1981, â€˜Whip Itâ€™ was way ahead of its time, defining the mid-â€™80s sound years before everybody else realized the power of weird hats, quirky lyrics and a firm embrace of your inner dork. Hell, theyâ€™re still ahead of their time.

48. â€˜Total Eclipse of the Heartâ€™ by Bonnie Tyler

Nobody writes grandiose heartbreak like Jim Steinman, and heâ€™s never done it better than in this smash 1983 epic ballad for the raspy-voiced Welsh belter Bonnie Tyler. â€˜Total Eclipse of the Heartâ€™ was originally conceived as a song for a vampire â€“ it even showed up later in Steinmanâ€™s 2002 Broadway fiasco, Dance of the Vampires â€“ and its gothic underpinnings are front and center in the songâ€™s lurid video. This is longing on a supernatural scale, and Tyler holds her own against the thundering arrangement as she roars out some of the least quiet desperation ever known to pop music.

Advertising
